reviewText: I saw this video on You Tube and knew I had to have it. It's probably the best video I've seen of them and they performed remarkably  great. Both in their mid 40's at the time of the concert their voices still sound to me as they always did. I've watched it several times already and the extra footage gives you more insight of them and their travels. It was good to see them back together as I hadn't heard anything about them since their breakup in 1973. I was greatly saddened to learn recently of Phil passing away. I remember the Everly Brothers well from the late 50's and 60's and they were a great part of my growing up.If you remember the Everly Brothers or just want to listen to the best harmony in a duo this is it. I've read that had it not been for the Everly Brothers there wouldn't have been a Simon and Garfunkle, Beetles, and others. They set the stage for all who followed them and it's sad to see this legacy gone but for the memories.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I wish this had more of the concert included, but what is here is wonderful. It includes the medley of Message to Mary/Maybe Tomorrow instead of So Sad, but I have the CDs that include both. They aren't the most engaging entertainers as they do more performing of their songs rather than conversing with the audience, and they never really looked beyond each other or the band behind them. I saw them live twice and both times found the way they keep their focus on each other, their guitars, even the floor of the stage rather than looking at the audience was surprising for rock 'n roll. Very limited dialog, though what is there is pleasant. I happily watch this frequently while listening to the beautiful songs they included on this tour.

reviewText: Not even the most peripheral rock 'n' roller should need any explanation whatsoever at this point regarding how two young Kentucky-bred brothers placed a stamp upon the Sounds of the Sixties equaled only by Buddy Holly and his Crickets:  One listen to nearly every Lennon and McCartney vocal duet from "Love Me Do" onwards - not to mention those most blatant protégés by the name of Simon and Garfunkel - more than prove that particular sonic point.Then there are albums such asSongs Our Daddy Taught Usand the ever-amazingRootswhich created the undeniable, if criminally under-acknowledged template for the Folk- and/or Country-rock of any Dylan, Byrds, or even Rank and File track you'd care to name-check. "We owe those guys everything," the man I like to call Bob is on record as admitting. "They started it all."Plus need I even mention a staggering string of globe and genre-spanning hit records which continue to reverberate within the DNA of popular music creators and listeners to this very day?Absolutely not. But what I feel I do need to state here and now, however, is the DVD release of "The Everly Brothers Reunion Concert: Live At The Royal Albert Hall," now here for all to watch, weep, and learn from.Ending their first run beneath the spotlight with a literally explosive on-stage break-up in 1973 - culminating with Don Everly's caustic statement "The Everly Brothers died ten years ago" - the pair saw and spoke with one another only once (at their father's funeral) during the ensuing downcast decade. Not surprisingly though, I suspect, as one can imagine little constructive musical place for the duo throughout an era book-ended by "Bad, Bad Leroy Brown" and "Billie Jean."But in finally burying various personal and musical hatchets ("We settled it in a family kind of way," Phil Everly told the Associated Press. "A big hug did it. I guess fate just turned"), the brothers returned to the country which always seemed to not only love, but understand them most with a 1983 performance in London. There, somehow, it took only twenty-five songs in less than an hour and a half to forever erase the years of bickering, brawling, bitterness and deeply-seeded sibling rivalry."The Everly Brothers Reunion Concert" presents it all. Every roll of the tom-toms, every country-baked guitar lick (courtesy of the stupendous Albert Lee), every thrash of Don's signature acoustic and, of course, every note-and-inflection-perfect vocal duet still dripping pathos one bar, then grating passion the next. As only these two Everlys honestly ever could.Rounding out this superb package is the (unfortunately truncated, however) 1984 documentary "Rock 'n' Roll Odyssey," which chronicles not only the songs and successes, but strains and struggles behind this most often completely misrepresented act. And it is most apt, perhaps, that nearly every frame of contemporary footage shot for this film finds Don and Phil being chased with persistent rainfall, be they driving through their childhood hills of bluegrass or arriving in England to sound-check, face the press, and reconnect with their most ever-loyal fan base. "If I wait for cloudy skies, you won't know the rain from the tears in my eyes" after all, as their own song still goes.Of course the Everlys followed their Royal Albert triumph with one P. McCartney-penned hit (the soaring "On The Wings Of A Nightingale") and landmark album (1986'sBorn Yesterday) which returned the duo to a much-deserved critical, if sorrowfully not commercial level unsurpassed since their late Fifties/early Sixties achievements. In fact an older, wiser, and most definitely still vital Don and Phil continue to harmonize on stage to this very day, though all attempts to get the brothers recording again (save for a lone track climaxing their 4-CD 1994 career retrospectiveHeartaches & Harmoniesplus a song from Andrew Lloyd Webber's "Whistle Down The Wind" four years later) have failed. But then, as no less an authority on the subject as Don Everly himself stated in his own inimitable manner, "I don't know whether there's a place for us. Country music's turned into a kind of a video soap opera - a contest of cute butts and pretty faces."I was raised in front of a microphone, and on the other side of the microphone was an audience. So it got instilled in me from the beginning:  You go out there and do your best, and if they appreciate it, that's the reward."Your reward? Reveling anew in Don and Phil's "Reunion Concert," and with it the fantastic flood of heartaches and harmonies those Everlys forever bring your way.
summary: Don and Phil Walk Right Back: The Everlys Reunion That Stuck

reviewText: The Everly Brothers out do themselves in this live performance.  Being on DVD let's you watch them sing while they sway the audience with their humor and appreciation to the audience.This is why you can buy CD's for a dime a dozen but seeing your favorite songs done by the ones that made them famous on dvd is a special treat.  I wish that more of these performances were done in Blue-Ray as the quality leaves you front row to watch your performer as if you were there.Jeff C.
summary: Everly Brothers Reuion at Albert Hall on DVD

reviewText: There were in fact 33 songs performed on that special including my favourite "Gone Gone Gone."  10 songs are missing from this DVD and in fact from some versions of the CD. There is only one CD collection that includes them all.Don't get me wrong.  This is classic wonderful Everly's; but the whole show should be here.  If it ever gets released I'll be happy to give it 5 stars.
summary: Would Have Given 5 Stars If Whole Concert Was Included

reviewText: I don't believe I have ever seen the Everly's perform. I only own a "greatest hits" CD from the original recordings. The concert was very entertaining and the music upgraded  in a sense with faster tempos and more instrument solos. I thought the voices were more interesting in this concert as the brothers expanded some of the songs and seemed completely comfortable with their solo and duo work. I highly recommend this if you are not really familiar with the Everly's career like me. The documentary is quite interesting as well focusing on their beginnings and influences.

reviewText: The cd came promptly well within the time limit. The quality was good. The acoustics at the Royal Albert Hall are always great. These musical icons have had such an influence on modern music. It is good to hear anything they do to get back to the source of a lot of present day music.

reviewText: I was wondering why the new issue of this long time favorite on VHS and then DVD....but the extra running time caught my eye.  I found it today at my local fye store and the extra 45 minutes is a documentary I'd seen on TV called "Rock N Roll Odyssey" which is a fabulous retrospective with not  only plenty of Everly Brothers on camera but Chet Atkins  and other legends who influenced and worked with the boys!  I purchased it for under $10 and consider it essential to any great Rock/Pop  music collection... I'd keep it next to the Simon & Garfunkel reunion  DVD (which The Everly's guested on) as a great pair!RECOMMENDED!!!
summary: GREAT Reunion show PLUS bonus 45 minute documentary!

reviewText: After an incredibly successful career, Phil and Don Everly split up in 1973 and according to many reports, did not speak to each other for ten years.  In 1983 this legendary duo reunited at London's Royal Albert Hall.  On September 14th, Eagle Records re-released the concert on DVD.  Though the concert has been released in many formats over the years, this release includes the documentary "Rock and Roll Odyssey".The Everly Brothers had an amazing career that included 26 Billboard Top 40 Singles. They were among the first ten artists inducted into the Rock and toll Hall of Fame, and received the Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award in 1997.  Many artists of the fifties and sixties credit Phil and Don with being an influence on their music including The Bee Gees, the Beach Boys, and the Beatles.For a duo with this much talent to go silent for ten years, a reunion was a huge event, and it certainly was in 1983.  Twenty-seven years after the fact; the event has lost a bit of its cache.  Sure, this is an enjoyable way to spend some time if you have not already seen it, but most people already have.  These two men are amazing, and they sound great here, but there is not a lot going on to watch as the two stand side by side with their acoustic guitars and sing the classics.  There is little banter, much less movement, and the stage lighting is somewhat annoying, and so it makes a better show to listen to than to watch.The production seems to have missed some obvious opportunities.  As the show opens with the two men entering the performance area through the audience, one cannot help but wonder where the behind the scenes shots are.  Pre-show performer and audience interviews are fairly standard on concert films as are performer arrivals, accelerated shots of the auditorium filling up, etc.  What you get here is the concert.  Not a bad product, but one that certainly fails to capture the excitement of the event.The draw here should be "Rock and Roll Odyssey" the documentary which is touted on the packaging as telling "the whole story of the Everly Brothers rise, fall, and renaissance."  Unfortunately the documentary fails to live up to the hype.  "Rock and Roll Odyssey" is nothing more than a collection of poorly recorded segments that lack continuity and provides little information or entertainment.Recommendation:  If there are Everly Brothers fans out there that do not own this concert, this will be a great purchase.  Don and Phil look and sound great on this DVD and the sound quality is excellent. Those looking for more insight into the career of one of the greatest musical duos of all time by owning the documentary "Rock and Roll Odyssey" are sure to be disappointed.
summary: The Everly Brothers Reunion Concert: Live at The Royal Albert Hall
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Reunion Concert at Albert Hall has been out on VHS and even DVD for years. It contains most of the big EB hits and a section of songs from the "Songs our Daddy Taught Us" Lp. The band is led by the great guitarist Albert Lee. So if you've never seen this, its worth picking up.As an added bonus is the 1983 documentary on the Brothers titled "Rock and Roll Odyssey. The original R&RO; ran 73 minutes but may have been pared done for this release based on another reviewers comment that its 45 minutes long here.Still, the DVD is budget priced so its definitely worth picking up if you don't have it already. Sort of a "Greatest Hits Live" DVD.Steve Ramm"Anything Phonographic"
summary: Nothing new here but the bonus documentary makes this a MUST HAVE for anyone who doesn't have the previous Concert Release.
